paragraphs.name: db73
paragraphs.text: MERCI - domo arigato! — THANX for this awesome article!!! sincere admiration and deep respect for 2 Japanese geniuses of all times — icons and living legends… been to Japan 5 times, seen the famous conductor once and did read all Haruki’s masterpieces… ❤

Thanks for going well beyond notions of “success”, “performance” , “productivity”, “goals”, “creativity” and even “vision”, and into the spiritual nature of truly fulfilling work, which is indistinguishable from life lived on the same spiritual basis.

8b070b02e725.title: Thanks for going well beyond notions of “success”, “performance” , “productivity”, “goals”,…

paragraphs.name: fd25
paragraphs.text: “The point is that you do not love yourself — otherwise you would love both your own nature and her purpose for you. Other men love their own pursuit and absorb themselves in its performance to the exclusion of bath and food […] these people, when impassioned, give up food and sleep for the promotion of their pursuits.” — Marcus Aurelius, Meditations, Para 3, Book 5.

597bbc90d35d.title: That’s the way I work too …

paragraphs.text: I feel the same. I’m nowhere near as great, but I have that river of creativity pulsing in my veins — of course I seem mad. I want to be a part of something bigger than myself, as anyone with a creative bone in their body, wants to be.

paragraphs.text: “…he has to do this.” Wonderfully written, and so, so true. Thank you!

74bcce0c7e3c.title: “…he has to do this.” Wonderfully written, and so, so true. Thank you!

paragraphs.text: Flow is so beautiful. It is always an echo though, which is part of its beauty. You are never aware of it until it is dissipating making it a memory like a reverberation of energy and emotion, or lack of actually. It’s a feeling of peace that resonates like our heartbeat slowing. You know you were somewhere gloriously connected to all the right…

paragraphs.name: 633d
paragraphs.text: “First of all, both of us seem to take the same simple joy in our work. Whatever differences there might be between making music and writing fiction, both of us are happiest when absorbed in our work. And the very fact that we are able to become so totally engrossed in it gives us the deepest satisfaction. What we end up producing as a result of that work may well be important, but aside from that, our ability to work with utter concentration and to devote ourselves to it so completely that we forget the passage of time is its own irreplaceable reward.”

paragraphs.name: f80a
paragraphs.text: Diagnosed with esophageal cancer, the famed Japanese conductor was rushed to the hospital. At 75 years of age, there was no guarantee he would survive.

paragraphs.name: d628
paragraphs.text: “I too wanted to say to him, “You really ought to hold off a little, take some time to recover, and start performing after you’ve got your strength back. I understand how you feel, but you know what they say — ‘Slow and steady wins the race.’ ” Really that was the only reasonable response, but I couldn’t bring myself to say it to him when I saw him wringing every ounce of strength out of his body to stand upright on the podium. I felt that those words would become a lie once I spoke them. To put it simply, this man was living in a world that transcended reasonable ways of thinking…”

paragraphs.name: 9e85
paragraphs.text: The third of our shared traits is stubbornness. We’re patient, tough, and, finally, just plain stubborn. Once we’ve decided to do something in a certain way, it doesn’t matter what anybody else says, that’s how we’re going to do it. And even if, as a result, we find ourselves in dire straits, possibly even hated, we will take responsibility for our actions without making excuses.

paragraphs.name: 20d7
paragraphs.text: They only look crazy to us.
